question.title: What is the difference between public, protected, package-private and private in Java?
question.body: In Java, are there clear rules on when to use each of access modifiers, namely the default (package private), public, protected and private, while making class and interface and dealing with inheritance?

answers.body:
(this is theoretically a comment on this answer but I write it here due to space restrictions, see my comment there)

The mentioned answer (and many others that are more or less writing the same) is vague or incomplete regarding the private modifier. It simply says, private means "accessible by the same class".

Here is an example proving that wrong (or incomplete -- see the parts marked with AAA! All lines that give a compile error are commented out and marked with the word "error" at the end of line):

class SuperClass {
    void superDefaultMethod() {}
    private void superPrivateMethod() {}
    protected void superProtectedMethod() {}
    public void superPublicMethod() {}
    private int superVar;
}


class MyClass extends SuperClass
{

    void thisDefaultMethod(){}
    private void thisPrivateMethod(){}
    protected void thisProtectedMethod(){}
    public void thisPublicMethod(){}
    private int thisVar;

    public MyClass()
    {
        // access superclass methods
        superDefaultMethod(); // OK
        // privateMethod() ; error
        superProtectedMethod(); // OK
        superPublicMethod(); // OK
        // and member variables
        // System.out.println(superVar); error

        // access own methods
        thisDefaultMethod();
        thisPrivateMethod();
        thisProtectedMethod();
        thisPublicMethod();
        // and member variables
        System.out.println(thisVar);
    }

    public void accessTest(MyClass other)
    {
        // access superclass methods but in another object of same class
        other.superDefaultMethod(); // OK
        // other.privateMethod() ; error!
        other.superProtectedMethod(); // OK
        other.superPublicMethod(); // OK
        // System.out.println(other.superVar); error

        // access this classes methods but in another object of same class
        other.thisDefaultMethod(); // OK
        // other.thisprivateMethod() ; error! Even if it is the same class! AAA!
        other.thisProtectedMethod(); // OK
        other.thisPublicMethod(); // OK

        System.out.println(other.thisVar); // this on the other hand is allowed AAA!
    }

// and a case when access to private member is allowed even if it is in different class
    static class InnerOne
    {
        private int value;
        private void method() {}
    }

    static class InnerTwo extends MyClass
    {
        int getOne(InnerOne other)
        {
            other.method();
            return other.value;
        }
    }

The second case marked where a private field is accessible even if it is in another class is described in this answer on a related question.

Also this answer here partly addresses the issue (see the direct or reference access).

The official tutorial may be of some use to you.

Class Package Subclass
(same pkg)		 Subclass
(diff pkg)		 World
public ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅
protected ✅ ✅ ✅ ✅ ❌
no modifier ✅ ✅ ✅ ❌ ❌
private ✅ ❌ ❌ ❌ ❌

✅: accessible
❌: not accessible
